questions.question:
Question 1: Which of the following is not expected to increase as an immediate response to surgical stress 
or trauma?
questions.explanation:
Insulin levels in plasma are decreased in the immediate ebb phase of surgical stress or trauma. There are three phases in the physiological response to injury: • Ebb phase • Flow phase • Recovery phase. The ebb phase begins at the time of injury and is characterized by hypovolemia and decreased 
basal metabolic rate. The predominant hormones regulating the ebb phase are catecholamines, 
cortisol, and aldosterone. The following mechanism leads to a reduction in insulin secretion during this phase: Pro-inflammatory cytokines like interleukin-1, tumour necrosis factor , IL-6 and IL-8 are 
produced within the first 24 hours of injury. In the later flow phase, insulin secretion begins to normalize i.e., relatively increases. However, 
insulin resistance by target cells occurs because of a defect in the insulin receptor/intracellular 
signalling pathway. Thus, the perioperative period is characterized by a state of functional insulin deficiency. 136

questions.question: Question 3: The components of the Revised Trauma Score (RTS) include which of the following:
questions.explanation:
The Revised Trauma Score (RTS) is a physiologic scoring system based on the initial vital signs of 
a trauma patient. Revised Trauma Score (RTS) includes : • Glasgow coma scale • Respiratory rate • Systolic BP The score range is 0–12. A lower score indicates a higher severity of injury.

questions.question: Question 4: Trauma and Injury Severity Score (TRISS) includes which of the following components?
questions.explanation:
TRISS (Trauma and Injury Severity Score) includes : • Injury Severity Score (ISS) • Revised Trauma Score (RTS) • Age • Mechanism of injury (blunt/penetrating). 137

questions.question:
Question 5: A 22-year-old man sustained a roller crush injury of his left arm up to mid-humerus and was 
brought to the casualty. The duty orthopedician uses the MESS score to decide about limb 
salvage. The score does not include which of the following?
questions.explanation: Neurogenic injury is not included in the Mangled Extremity Severity Score (MESS). The Mangled Extremity Severity Score (MESS) is useful in deciding about limb salvage. The components of the Mangled Extremity Severity score are: • The energy that caused the injury, skeletal and soft tissue injury • Limb ischemia • Shock • Age of the patient.

questions.question:
Question 6: Diagnostic peritoneal lavage is being done in a patient with suspected hemoperitoneum. 
Which of the following statements is not true?

options.a: Presence of more than 100,000 RBCs/mm3 is a positive finding
options.b: Presence of more than 200 white cells/mm3 is a positive finding
options.c: Aspiration of at least 10 mL of gross blood is an indication for laparotomy
options.d: Amylase levels more than 175 units/dL is a positive finding

questions.explanation:
The presence of more than 500 white cells/mm3 in blunt trauma indicates a positive finding of 
diagnostic peritoneal lavage. Diagnostic peritoneal lavage detects the presence of intraperitoneal blood. Its use has decreased to 
virtually nil at many centres with the advent of the FAST examination. Indications for diagnostic peritoneal lavage are: • Abdominal pain or tenderness • Low abdominal rib fractures • Unexplained hypotension • Spinal or pelvic fractures • Paraplegia or quadriplegia • Assessment hampered by altered mental status due to neurologic injury or intoxication. Procedure: It is performed through a small infraumbilical incision with the placement of the catheter under 
direct vision. The supraumbilical approach is indicated in pregnant patients and those with pelvic 
fractures. Aspiration of at least 10 mL of gross blood is an indication for laparotomy. If no blood is aspirated, a catheter is placed and 1 L of Ringer lactate solution is instilled into the 
peritoneal cavity and then allowed to drain by gravity. At least 200 mL of lavage fluid should be 
recovered to allow for accurate interpretation. Disadvantages: • Neither qualitative nor quantitative • Cannot identify the source of hemorrhage • Relatively small amounts of intraperitoneal bleeding may result in a positive study • May not detect small and large injuries to the diaphragm • Cannot rule out injury to the bowel or retroperitoneal organs. 138 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 7: A 32-year-old professional boxer was brought to the emergency department following a blow 
to the abdomen. On examination, his vitals were normal, and his abdomen was tender on 
palpation. Which among the following is the best modality to assess the injury to the 
abdominal organs for this patient?
questions.explanation:
A contrast-enhanced CT scan is the best diagnostic modality (gold standard) for stable patients 
with blunt trauma to the abdomen. It is a non-invasive and sensitive investigation. It can identify haemorrhage, intraabdominal as 
well as retroperitoneal organ injury. However, performing CECT is time-consuming (when 
compared to FAST) and therefore it can be used only in stable patients. FAST ultrasound is a limited examination directed to look for intraperitoneal fluid or pericardial 
injury as a marker of the underlying injury. The best imaging modality for hemodynamically 
unstable patients with blunt trauma of the abdomen is FAST.

questions.question:
Question 8: 131 
Sold by @itachibot A young man is brought to the trauma unit following a road traffic accident. He is 
hemodynamically unstable. As an adjunct to the primary survey, the managing surgeon 
decides to do a FAST. Which of the following areas would not be visualized in this procedure?
questions.explanation:
The left lower quadrant is not assessed in FAST examination. FAST (Focused Assessment with Sonography for Trauma) is a rapid diagnostic examination to 
assess patients with potential thoracoabdominal injuries. FAST also stands for Focussed abdominal sonography for trauma. However, since FAST is not 
only used to assess abdominal injuries but also to assess haemopericardium in cases of pericardial 
injuries, the expansion Focussed assessment with sonography for trauma is preferred. It can be 
performed within 2-4 minutes. Technique of FAST examination: With the patient in the supine position, a 3.5-5.0 MHz convex transducer is used. Four regions may be scanned: • Subxiphoid transverse view - To assess for pericardial effusion and left lobe liver injuries • Longitudinal view of the right upper quadrant - To assess for right liver injuries, right kidney 
injury, and Morrison's pouch. • Longitudinal view of the left upper quadrant - To assess for splenic injury and left kidney injury. • Transverse and longitudinal views of the suprapubic region - To assess the bladder and pouch of 
Douglas. In an extended FAST or eFAST scan, left and right thoracic views are used to assess for 
pneumothorax and haemothorax.

questions.question: Question 9: Which of the following describes the correct sequence of evaluation in the FAST technique?

options.a: Pericardial sac  Perihepatic region  Perisplenic region  Pelvis
options.b: Perihepatic region  Perisplenic region  Pelvis  Pericardial sac
options.c: Pelvis  Pericardial sac  Perisplenic region  Perihepatic region
options.d: Perisplenic region  Perihepatic region  Pericardial sac  Pelvis

questions.explanation:
The correct sequence of evaluation in the FAST technique is Pericardial sac  Perihepatic region 
 Perisplenic region  Pelvis. 139

questions.question:
Question 10: A patient with a history of blunt trauma is brought to the casualty and an eFAST examination 
is performed. Which of the following statements about the investigation is false?

options.a: B-lines indicate a normal ultrasonographic finding of the lung
options.b: Stratosphere sign seen in M-mode USG is indicative of pneumothorax
options.c: It can be reliably used to detect less than 100 mL of free blood
options.d: It is unreliable for the assessment of the retroperitoneum

questions.explanation:
FAST is not reliable in detecting less than 100 mL of free blood. Disadvantages of FAST: • Does not directly identify injury to hollow viscus • Cannot reliably exclude injury in penetrating trauma • Unreliable for the assessment of the retroperitoneum. B-lines or "comet trails" are echogenic bright linear reflections beneath the pleura that are usually 
lost with any air between the probe and the lung tissue. B-lines’ are expected in normal aerated lung and are visualized moving along with the sliding 
pleura. Excessive ‘B-lines’, especially in the anterior lung, are abnormal and are usually indicative 
of interstitial edema. Therefore, the presence of B-lines along with seashore sign indicates the absence of 
pneumothorax. The image below shows the seashore sign. Barcode sign which is also known as the stratosphere sign and lack of sliding movement in the 
lungs diagnosed by an M-mode USG is suggestive of pneumothorax. 140 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 11: An intensivist is evaluating a patient for brain stem death in the ICU. Presence of which of the 
following features should not be misinterpreted as evidence for normal brainstem function in 
this patient?
questions.explanation:
Babinski reflex, tachycardia, and normal systolic blood pressure can be occasionally seen in 
patients with brain stem death. So, this should not be misinterpreted as evidence for normal 
brainstem function Brain death is not characterized by decerebrate or decorticate posturing, which is a 
brain-originating motor response. Brainstem death is defined as the irreversible loss of cerebral and brain-stem function. Ideal criteria for brain stem death contain three essential elements: • Widespread cortical destruction that is re■ected by deep coma and unresponsiveness to all 
forms of stimulation • Global brainstem damage demonstrated by absent pupillary light reaction and by the loss of 
oculovestibular and corneal re■exes • Destruction of the medulla manifested by complete and irreversible apnea. Brainstem death entails testing twice, by two clinicians, to demonstrate the absence of: • Response to pain • Respiratory drive (apnea despite arterial PCO2  60 mm Hg ) • Pupillary light reflex • Corneal reflex • Vestibulo-ocular reflex • Oculo-cephalic reflex The following manifestations are occasionally seen in brain dead patients and should not be 
misinterpreted as evidence for brainstem function: 141 
Sold by @itachibot • Normal systolic blood pressure >100 mmHg • Movements originating from the spinal cord or peripheral nerve may occur • Sweating, flushing, tachycardia • Deep tendon reflexes, superficial abdominal reflexes, triple flexion response • Babinski reflex • Spontaneous movements of limbs other than pathologic flexion or extension response • Respiratory-like movements (shoulder elevation and adduction, back-arching, intercostal 
expansion without significant tidal volumes).

questions.question: Question 12: Which of the following is false regarding imaging in the primary survey of a trauma patient?

options.a: Hemodynamically unstable patient should not be sent for CT scan
options.b: All patients should have chest X-ray PA view only
options.c: X-ray of the pelvis is essential in primary survery
options.d: X-rays in primary survey must also be done in pregnant women

questions.explanation:
Chest X-ray and X-ray pelvis are taken in AP view in the adjuncts to the primary survey of a 
trauma patient.

questions.question: Question 13: Which of the following is not a part of the primary survey?

options.b: Removing clothes to inspect for wounds
options.c: Taking CT scan of the patient

questions.explanation:
Taking a CT scan of the patient is a part of secondary survey. Primary survey identifies and manages the most immediately life-threatening pathologies first. The secondary survey includes investigations that help identify all other injuries, excluding the 
apparent ones. This includes X-rays of the spine and extremities and a CT of the abdomen, head, 
chest, and spine.

questions.question:
Question 14: A patient who sustained an RTA was brought to the ER in a semiconscious state. He makes 
incoherent sounds, withdraws from painful stimuli, and opens his eyes to painful stimuli. 
Calculate his GCS score.
questions.explanation: The GCS score in this patient is 8. Withdraws from pain = 4 Incoherent sounds = 2 Opens eyes to painful stimuli = 2 Total GCS score = 4 + 2 + 2 = 8.

questions.question:
Question 15: A patient who was admitted after a road traffic accident is put on mechanical ventilation. He 
opens his eyes on verbal command and moves all four limbs spontaneously. Calculate his 
GCS.
questions.explanation:
The patients GCS is Eyes-3, Verbal-NT, Motor-6. It is calculated as follows: • Eye opening: Opening to verbal command - 3 142 
Sold by @itachibot • Verbal response: In the case of endotracheal intubation, the verbal response score is noted as NT 
(non-testable) • Motor respone: Movement of all 4 limbs spontaneously - 6 Total GCS score is not recorded since one of the components is non-testable.

questions.question: Question 16: Which of the following is considered balanced resuscitation?

options.c: Maintain ph by ensuring acid-base balance
options.d: Fluid resuscitation by giving colloids and crystalloids

questions.explanation:
Permissive hypotension is a part of balanced resuscitation in trauma management to avoid 
bleeding. Damage control resuscitation (DCR) i.e. balanced resuscitation is used in the settings of major 
trauma. It aims to control hemorrhage and prevent coagulopathy prior to the development of the 
trauma triad of death (hypothermia, acidosis, and coagulopathy). The components of DCR 
include: • Permissive hypotension until definitive surgical control • Minimize crystalloid based resuscitation • Early use of blood products (PRBCs, FFP, platelets, cryoprecipitate) in the ratio of 1:1:1 • Use of hemostatic agents such as tranexamic acid, recombinant factor 7a, prothrombin complex 
concentrates DCR has the following advantages: • Minimizes the impact of trauma-induced coagulopathy • Limits blood product waste • Reduces the complications that occur with aggressive crystalloid resuscitation.

questions.question:
Question 17: Which of the following drugs have a significant role in the mortality reduction of trauma 
patients based on the CRASH-2 trial?
questions.explanation:
The CRASH-2 trial has shown mortality reduction in bleeding trauma patients by early usage of 
tranexamic acid (preferably within the first 3 hours) with a loading dose of 1 g over 10 minutes 
and then infusion of 1 g over 8 hours.

questions.question:
Question 18: In a patient with massive haemorrhage, damage control surgery is being performed. What 
does this consist of?
questions.explanation:
Damage Control Surgery refers to performing limited surgical intervention in order to arrest 
hemorrhage, control sepsis, and protect from further injury. This concept of tailoring the operation to match the patient’s physiology and staged procedures to 
prevent physiological exhaustion is called Damage Control Surgery. Furthermore, definitive repairs are delayed and not until the patient is hemodynamically stable 
and physiologically capable of sustaining the procedure. Crystalloid and colloid infusions are 143 
Sold by @itachibot limited in order to avoid dilutional coagulopathy. The term Damage Control Surgery is borrowed from the military, which ensures the continued 
functioning of a damaged ship above conducting complete repairs which would prevent a rapid 
return to battle.

questions.question:
Question 19: A young man sustained multiple injuries following a road traffic accident. On examination, 
his pulse rate is 100/min and BP is 85/60 mmHg. He is diagnosed with pelvic fracture and is 
suspected to have retroperitoneal hemorrhage. Which of the following statements is true? 134 
Sold by @itachibot

options.a: Coagulopathy is corrected in phase II of damage control surgery
options.b: Definitive repair of injuries is done 12-24 hours after phase III
options.c: Internal iliac artery ligation is done in phase II
options.d: Hypothermia and acidosis are corrected in phase I

questions.explanation:
Coagulopathy is corrected in phase II of Damage Control Surgery. Damage control surgery is minimal intervention done to stabilize the patient and do the definite 
surgery later. It centers on coordinating staged operative interventions with periods of aggressive 
resuscitation to salvage trauma patients sustaining major injuries. It consists of three phases: • Phase I - Initial Exploration: This phase consists of an initial operative exploration to attain 
rapid control of active haemorrhage and contamination. • Phase II - Secondary Resuscitation: This phase focuses on secondary resuscitation to correct 
hypothermia, coagulopathy, and acidosis. • Phase III - Definitive Operation: It consists of planned re-exploration and definitive repair of 
injuries. This phase typically occurs 48 to 72 hours following initial and after successful secondary 
resuscitation.

questions.question: Question 20: Which of the following is not a component of the trauma triad of death?
questions.explanation:
Shock is not considered to be a component of the trauma triad of death. The trauma triad of death is a combination of clinical features that are seen in exsanguinating 
trauma patients and contribute to the majority of trauma-related mortality and morbidities. The 
triad includes: • Hypothermia • Coagulopathy • Acidosis During the resuscitation phase of trauma, adequate precautions should be taken to prevent the 
development of these features. • Hypothermia is prevented by maintenance of ambient temperature within the patient’s room, 
usage of prewarmed iv fluids, blankets, etc. • Coagulopathy can be prevented by judicious use of i.v crystalloids (<1-1.5 Lit), early initiation 
of blood and blood products, usage of tranexamic acid, etc. • Acidosis can be prevented by correction of shock, ensuring adequate oxygenation, usage of 
sodium bicarbonate, etc. 144 
Sold by @itachibot Trauma - Spinal, Thoracic and Abdominal Injuries
